title: 105_s573
content: The "Loan Interest Forgiveness for Education Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a deduction for interest on education loans under section 221. The deduction for interest on qualified education loans is allowed for individuals. The deduction amount is reduced if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds certain limits. Adjusted gross income is determined without considering specific sections and after applying certain provisions. For inflation adjustment, the amounts mentioned in the paragraph will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The taxable year begins in 1996 instead of 1992. Amounts adjusted under paragraph (3) are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. No deduction is allowed if another taxpayer claims a deduction for the same individual. A qualified education loan is defined as indebtedness for qualified higher education expenses. The term 'qualified education loan' includes indebtedness for education expenses incurred before or after the loan was taken, related to education during at least half-time enrollment. It excludes loans owed to related persons and can be used to refinance other qualified education loans. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' refers to the cost of attendance at an eligible educational institution, excluding certain amounts, and includes institutions offering internship or residency programs leading to a degree or certificate. The term 'half-time student' refers to an individual who would be a student if 'half-time' were substituted for 'full-time' in the definition. The term 'dependent' has the meaning given in section 152. Special rules include denial of double benefits and the requirement for married couples to file a joint return for the deduction under subsection (a). The deduction for interest on education loans is allowed if the taxpayer and their spouse file a joint return. Marital status is determined according to section 7703. The reporting requirement is amended by adding a new section after 6050R in the Internal Revenue Code. "SEC. 6050S. RETURNS RELATING TO EDUCATION LOAN INTEREST RECEIVED IN TRADE OR BUSINESS FROM INDIVIDUALS." Any person engaged in a trade or business who receives $600 or more in interest on qualified education loans from an individual must file a return with the IRS. The return must include the individual's name, address, TIN, and the amount of interest received for the calendar year. The IRS requires any person engaged in a trade or business who receives $600 or more in interest on qualified education loans from an individual to file a return. This return must include the individual's name, address, TIN, and the amount of interest received for the calendar year. Governmental units are also included in the definition of 'person' for this purpose, with special rules and designated officers or employees responsible for making the required returns. Every person required to file a return must provide a written statement to each individual showing the name, address, and total interest received. The statement must be given by January 31 of the following year. The term 'qualified education loan' is defined as per section 221(d)(1) unless specified otherwise by the Secretary's regulations. The term 'qualified education loan' is defined as per section 221(d)(1). Interest received by one person on behalf of another person requires only the first recipient to file a return. Section 6724(d) of the Code is amended to include returns related to education loan interest received in trade or business. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include returns related to education loan interest received in trade or business from individuals. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 is also updated to reflect this change. The amendments made by this section apply to any qualified education loan incurred on, before, or after the date of the enactment of this Act, but only with respect to any loan interest payment due after December 31, 1996.
